description:
This adds the ability to do an annotated volume rendering, including drawing the transfer function and adding any user defined text.  E.g.,:

```
   sc.save_annotated("subchandra_test_annotated.png", 
                      text_annotate=[[(0.05, 0.05), 
                                      "t = {}".format(ds.current_time.d),
                                      dict(horizontalalignment="left")],
                                     [(0.5,0.95), 
                                      "Maestro simulation of He convection on a white dwarf",
                                      dict(color="y", fontsize="24",
                                           horizontalalignment="center")]])

```

will draw the transfer function and add two strings (with different sizes, alignments, and colors) to the image.  Producing, e.g.,

![subchandra_test_annotated.png](https://bitbucket.org/repo/45gxkn/images/822672585-subchandra_test_annotated.png)
title: port the save_annotated function from the old camera

pullrequest.title: port the save_annotated function from the old camera

content.raw: some bits were changed from the old camera interface.  For instance, instead of the generic `enhance`, there is now a `sigma_clip` which does the same thing as the normal `save`.  Also, the figure size respects what the user set for the original camera -- this way you know what size image you are getting.  It can be altered by using the `dpi` setting.
content.html: some bits were changed from the old camera interface. For instance, instead of the generic enhance, there is now a sigma_clip which does the same thing as the normal save. Also, the figure size respects what the user set for the original camera -- this way you know what size image you are getting. It can be altered by using the dpi setting.

pullrequest.title: port the save_annotated function from the old camera

content.raw:
In the PlotWindow interface, I made it so that annotations like `annotate_text()` could receive both an `x,y` value in the fixed window space, as well as a 3d data coordinate where you wanted to have text show up.  This is particularly useful if you want to track individual features in visualization rather than just painting a title or whatever over things at an arbitrary location.  It might be useful to have similar functionality in the VR interface, but this may be appropriate for a future PR if you don't feel like working on it here.

An example of what I mean with the `TextLabelCallback`: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/169c6b14377e4e691657a18547322d3d0c87aae3/yt/visualization/plot_modifications.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default#plot_modifications.py-1177

The actual code that does the conversion between `coord_system`: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/169c6b14377e4e691657a18547322d3d0c87aae3/yt/visualization/plot_modifications.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default#plot_modifications.py-58
content.html:
In the PlotWindow interface, I made it so that annotations like annotate_text() could receive both an x,y value in the fixed window space, as well as a 3d data coordinate where you wanted to have text show up. This is particularly useful if you want to track individual features in visualization rather than just painting a title or whatever over things at an arbitrary location. It might be useful to have similar functionality in the VR interface, but this may be appropriate for a future PR if you don't feel like working on it here.

An example of what I mean with the TextLabelCallback: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/169c6b14377e4e691657a18547322d3d0c87aae3/yt/visualization/plot_modifications.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default#plot_modifications.py-1177

The actual code that does the conversion between coord_system: https://bitbucket.org/yt_analysis/yt/src/169c6b14377e4e691657a18547322d3d0c87aae3/yt/visualization/plot_modifications.py?at=yt&fileviewer=file-view-default#plot_modifications.py-58

content.raw: yeah, I think that should be a separate PR.  But I agree that would be nice to have.  For now, I wanted to be able to label with the time, acknowledgements, titles, etc., which is usually needed for movies.
content.html: yeah, I think that should be a separate PR. But I agree that would be nice to have. For now, I wanted to be able to label with the time, acknowledgements, titles, etc., which is usually needed for movies.

content.raw: also, it is not enough to make the projected coords, because we use imshow to draw this and then the transfer function, we would need to convert data coordinates into normalized figure coords.
content.html: also, it is not enough to make the projected coords, because we use imshow to draw this and then the transfer function, we would need to convert data coordinates into normalized figure coords.

pullrequest.title: port the save_annotated function from the old camera

content.raw: That's true.  In PlotWindow, we use the project coordinates function in concert with the two functions immediately following it in the source to do all of this.  I think it should be relatively straightforward.
content.html: That's true. In PlotWindow, we use the project coordinates function in concert with the two functions immediately following it in the source to do all of this. I think it should be relatively straightforward.

http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/cookbook/complex_plots.html#volume-rendering-with-annotation

pullrequest.title: port the save_annotated function from the old camera

content.raw:
ok, fixed your comment.

Note there is also a minor fix to transfer_functions.py -- if we were trying to label a tick that had a value of '0', it would try to take the log of it to put it into scientific notation, and fun would ensue.  Now I explicitly check for 0, and it works great.
content.html:
ok, fixed your comment.

Note there is also a minor fix to transfer_functions.py -- if we were trying to label a tick that had a value of '0', it would try to take the log of it to put it into scientific notation, and fun would ensue. Now I explicitly check for 0, and it works great.

content.raw: I'm nervous about importing this at the top level, since it can cause a failure if it's an X11 frontend that doesn't have access to a display.
